channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Perl Superheroes Wanted! Remote Perl within US time zone
item.description: As the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions for clients that include first responders, engineers, manufacturers, and educators, this organization’s comprehensive offerings include training management, continuing education, compliance training, safety management, and workforce scheduling. Want in? They’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Bold, beautiful, and… brainy? Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: With all the knowledge in your big, beautiful brain, it’s time to join a company that appreciates your breadth of experience. Our client provides online trading services and with offices in Dubai, Malta, and Malaysia, they’ve got the global reach that may provide the challenge you’re looking for.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. Remote Perl role in the UK/EU
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues.

item.title: Continuous Integration (CI)
item.description: A collection of posts about Continuous Integration

item.title: Docker course
item.description: New parts of the Docker course were published

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 188
item.description: Just fall in love with Raku one-liner. Cool work, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 188
item.description: Bonus Python solution together with Perl being part of the blog post. Nice, well done.

item.title: Divisible Zero
item.description: Cool use of Euclid's algorithm for the task "Total Zero". Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Divisible pairs and reduce to nothing
item.description: Nice discussion of every aspect of the task, Great job.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 188
item.description: Master of Perl one-liners in action one more time. Keep it up great work.

item.title: I have no time this week!
item.description: I loved the parameter checking in the signature. Clean approach, well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 188: Divisible Pairs and Total Zero
item.description: Very clever coding, if you know Perl then you can easily Raku and if you know Raku you can easily follow Perl. Thanks to the great writing skill of Laurent.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 188
item.description: Plenty of variations with performance table. Well crafted solutions. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 188
item.description: Great demo of Raku power as one-liner. Highly Recommended.

item.title: PWC188 - Total Zero
item.description: I love the story telling style of blogging, it makes the blog fun to read. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: PWC188 - Divisible Pairs
item.description: Nice attempt to bring the maths behind the task. Loved it. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Zero Divisibility
item.description: Great detailed explanation makes the code easy to follow. Well done and thanks for sharing.

item.title: Challenge 188
item.description: Self documented and easy to follow solution in Raku. Keep it up.

item.title: Pairs Divided by Zero
item.description: Adam's approach to a task is exceptional. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 188
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Divisible Pairs" and "Total Zero" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 189
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Greater Character" and "Array Degree". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Blaming past self
item.description: Fun post and it is the story of every developer in my opinion. I found a subtle bug in one of my own CPAN module after 10 years. I don't want to name and shame it, though.

item.title: Certificates expiration
item.description: Have you ever dealt with certificate? If yes then you must read this post.

item.title: Cryptopals 38 - New insights from a kind reader
Pass4me
item.description: Interesting discusion to engage with. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

item.title: Typing foreach till the end
item.description: What do you prefer for or foreach?

item.description: Nice introduction to "scoop", command-line installer for Windows.

item.title: Light Git repository checkout
item.description: A very handy tutorial for those dealing with large git repository. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Hello and welcome!
item.description: A new website introduced for all Perl fans. Please go checkout.

item.title: Next stable DBD::SQLite will be released at the beginning of November
item.description: DBD::SQLite 1.71_07 (with SQLite 3.39.4) is a release candidate for the next stable DBD::SQLite.

item.title: Announcements from the Board
item.description: Official announcement of name change TPF to TPRF.

item.title: Personalized investment with Torto AI
item.description: Any investment in the stock market is partially based on objective data (e.g. P/E ratio) and partially on the subjective worldview of the investor (expected changes in inflation, politics, weather etc.) torto.ai works on providing you a platform where you can easily combine these aspects and find the investment that most suitable for your expectation.

item.title: #588 - TRPF, what’s in a name?
item.description:
Hi there,

Few days ago, I came across the official announcement with regard to the name change. I saw mixed reaction on Facebook groups for Perl fans.

So what is my (personal) view on the topic?

I understand name change is not an easy decision, it must have been going on for days if not months. My view is to keep Perl and Raku separate. Having said, I like the name change at least it is better than what it was before. Since we are talking about name change, my suggestion is why not change it back to "Yet Another Society (YAS)" as it was before if I am not mistaken. Then have two separate board under its wings i.e. "The Perl Foundation (TPF)" and "The Raku Foundation (TRF)". Also allow the individual board to decide the path they want to follow. This way we don't cross each others path and stay friendly. It sounds simple, isn't it? Not sure if it is easy to implement.

This name change brought back memories when I decided to change the name Perl Weekly Challenge. As you all know, right from day one, we decided to have both Perl and Raku as the main contributing languages. A few months later after the launch, I found the name not reflecting what actual happens on the ground. But I already had the domain perlweeklychallenge.org registered and all the actions were happening under the same domain. After discussing with some of my close friends, I decided to change it to a new domain, theweeklychallenge.org. To me, it makes more sense as we gradually opened up to many more languages, 92 to be precise as of today. It wasn't an easy decision for me to change the name and move everything to new domain. Gabor Szabo helped me with the domain switch and patch the old domain to divert trafic to the new domain. Everthing seems to be stable now but I still refer the team as Team PWC as it is very close to my heart.

How was your experience with Hacktoberfest 2022?

My contributions this time didn't meet the minimum requirement of the event. Although I submitted 4 Pull Requests and all of them were accepted and merged by the author but only 2 PR were counted as the other two PR were part of non-participating repositories. Having said, I am happy many of the Team PWC members got more than 4 Pull Requests this time. Congratulations Team PWC.

If you want to have fun and share your knowledge every week with others then please do join us here on The Weekly Challenge. Also please don't forget to checkout the experience of our champions.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
